centralQuestion: Should the power of the executive order be reduced?

reasons.description: Expanding executive orders threatens checks and balances and risks an 'imperial presidency.'

sources.title: Politico: 'How Biden Could Wind Down the Imperial Presidency'
Brookings Institution: 'Do eroding presidential norms undermine constitutional principles?'

reasons.description: Executive orders can produce policy whiplash, while durable change generally requires legislation.

sources.title: Center for American Progress: 'A 100 Percent Clean Future'
Associated Press: 'What is an executive order? A look at Trump's tool for quickly reshaping government'

reasons.description: Using executive orders to withhold or redirect congressionally appropriated funds undermines Congress’ power of the purse and invites illegality.

sources.title: Reuters: 'Explainer: Trump's spending pause and its legality'
Brookings Institution: 'GAO's role in appropriations oversight'

reasons.description: Efforts to curb nationwide injunctions and other judicial checks magnify the dangers of unchecked executive action.

sources.title: Politico: 'Trump asks Supreme Court to curb judges' power to block his policies nationwide'
The Guardian: 'The Guardian view on Trump’s tariffs: the courts have drawn a line. So must Congress'

objections.description: Executive orders are essential for swift action, especially when Congress is slow or gridlocked.

sources.title: AEI: 'Trump’s barrage of executive orders for education: How significant are they?'
PBS NewsHour: 'Trump unleashes wave of executive orders in promised overhaul of U.S. policies'

objections.description: Executive orders are already constrained by law and courts.

sources.title: Reuters: 'What can Trump do through executive orders?'
Brookings Institution: 'Will the Supreme Court weaken lower-court checks on Biden’s executive power?'

objections.description: Executive orders are a legitimate management tool to implement statutes; most orders are routine rather than sweeping.

sources.title: Brookings Institution: 'Obama’s Executive Orders; A Reality Check'
AEI: 'A rule of thumb for the executive power debates'

objections.description: Voters expect presidents to use available tools; allies often urge robust executive action when legislation stalls.

sources.title: Politico: 'Democrats to Biden: Go big on executive actions'
Brookings Institution: 'Biden’s AI order will deliver on its promises—if government uses every tool available'

research.title: Journal of Public Policy: 'Executive action that lasts'
research.description: Analyzes why many executive actions are never formally revoked and develops a measure of outcome immutability that can make unilateral actions more durable.

research.title: American Journal of Political Science: 'Legislative Capacity and Executive Unilateralism'
research.description: Shows presidents issue more executive orders when congressional capacity to constrain is low, and fewer when legislative capacity is high.

research.title: Legislative Studies Quarterly: 'Legislative Constraints on Executive Unilateralism in the United States'
research.description: Examines how Congress constrains presidential unilateral action and the conditions under which it is more or less likely to succeed.

research.title: Political Science Research and Methods: 'Persistent unilateral action'
research.description: Argues that persistence of unilateralism can arise from selection effects and policy feedbacks, explaining why some unilateral actions survive successors.
